questions.question: Most common rheumatic disease in children is
You are evaluating JIA patients in a pediatric rheumatology clinic. As per the ILAR criteria,which of the following patients would you not include under JIA?

options.C: A 18-year-old with RF negative Polyarthritis first diagnosed 3 years back

questions.explanation: Reactive arthritis is not a subtype of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) so you would not includethis subset of patients under your evaluation.ILAR (International League of Associations for Rheumatology) defines JIA as arthritis of one ormore joints with onset below 16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks.The subtypes of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA):-.Oligoarthritis (4 or lesser joints) (Most common type)• Polyarthritis (5 or more joints)• RF Positive• RF Negative•Systemic JIA•Psoriatic arthritis•Enthesitis-related arthritis• Undifferentiated

questions.question: Mohit is brought to the pediatrician by his mother because of red-eye. He complains ofblurring of vision and on examination, the pupil appears as shown in the picture. Which ofthe following subtype of JIA is associated with the highest risk for the ophthalmiccomplication noted in this patient?705
questions.explanation: The patient has red-eye and the blurring of vision along with the finding of the irregular pupil,which is suggestive of uveitis. ANA-positive oligoarthritis is associated with the highest risk foruveitis in patients with Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis.The presence of a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) confers increased risk for uveitis inchildren with JIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination every 3 months.

questions.question: A worried mother brings her 4-year-old girl who has been complaining about pain in thejoints of arms and legs for 2 months. On examination, multiple nodules over the bonyprominences suggestive of rheumatoid nodules are noted. On investigation, RA-factor wasfound positive pointing to the diagnosis of RF-positive polyarthritis. Which of the followingcomplication is not likely to occur in this patient?
questions.explanation: Ankylosis is not seen in patients with RF-positive Polyarthritis.Polyarthritis is characterized by inflammation of ≥5 joints in both upper and lower extremities.Rheumatoid factor (RF)-positive polyarthritis resembles the characteristic symmetricpresentation of adult rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid nodules on the extensor surfaces of theelbows, spine, and over the Achilles tendons are associated with a more severe course and almostexclusively occur in RF-positive individuals.Complications may include:•Micrognathia (due to chronic temporomandibular joint disease)• Cervical spine involvement, manifesting as decreased neck extension, occurs with a risk ofatlantoaxial subluxation and neurologic sequelae.•Hip disease may be subtle, with findings of erosion.713

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis?
questions.explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) factor is negative in systemic JIA. It is positive in a subtypeof polyarthritic type of JIA.Systemic JIA is characterized by a fever of at least 2 weeks and Arthritis in 1 or more joints + atleast one of• Evanescent erythematous rash• Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly• Generalized lymphadenopathy• Serositis

questions.question: Anuj, a school-going kid has been brought to the pediatric OPD by his mother withcomplaints of fever for 3 weeks. She says her son has been skipping school because of thefever but in the evening he gets better and plays with his siblings. She also noticed a rash thatappears along with fever and disappears spontaneously. He has a history of joint pain on andoff since pre-school. On examination, generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegalyare noted along with an evanescent erythematous rash on the trunk. Which of the followingcharacteristically defines the fever associated with this child's condition?
questions.explanation: The patient has clinical features of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA), which is associatedwith quotidian fever. Quotidian fever - fever that rises to 39°C (102.2°F) once a day and returns to37°C (98.6°F) between fever peaksSystemic JIA is characterized by a fever of at least 2 weeks and Arthritis in 1 or more joints + atleast one of•• Evanescent erythematous rash that is non-pruritic and migratory with lesions lasting<1 hr.• Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly• Generalized lymphadenopathy⚫ Serositis

questions.question: Aarav is a known case of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JI

options.A: . He is referred to a Rheumatologyspecialist center from a local hospital, when his condition started deteriorating on steroidtreatment. On examination, the patient has lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, andpurpura along with the acute onset of high spiking fevers. Vitals show persistent hypotension(85/45 mmHg), tachycardia (160/min), and oliguria. He was urgently admitted into the PICU.The resident physician is confused between macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) and JIAflare-up. Which of the following is best suited to distinguish these two?a) Hyperferritinemia

questions.explanation: Macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) is characterized by all of the listed features. However, thediagnosis is confirmed by bone marrow biopsy demonstrating hemophagocytosis and is the besttest to distinguish MAS from a flare-up of JIA.MAS is a rare but potentially fatal complication of systemic JIA. It is characterized by anuncontrolled activation and proliferation of T lymphocytes and macrophages. It is the result of acytokine storm that leads to a dysregulated inflammatory activation of the immune system, withrapid progression to multiorgan failure if not promptly diagnosed and properly treated. It ischaracterized by the following:• Macrophage hemophagocytosis in the bone marrow•⚫ Hypofibrinogenemia (paradoxical fall in erythrocyte sedimentation rate [ESR])⚫ Hypertriglyceridemia714• Extreme hyperferritinemia• Fever >38.5°C●Splenomegaly.Cytopenia affecting at least two of three cell lineagesTreatment usually includes high-dose corticosteroids and immunosuppressive agents in refractorycases.

questions.question: A mother brought her 12-day old baby to the OPD due to the rash shown in the picture for thelast 5 days. The mother says the rash gets worse in the sun. The infant was born at home andshe never had a prenatal check-up. She herself has a history of joint pains and a facial rashwhich she says is "no big deal". On examination, Vitals are normal for the baby. A subsequentECG shows P wave rate 120/min and R wave rate at 70/min with no relation between the two.707Which of the following antibodies will be used to diagnose this baby's condition?
questions.explanation: The baby has raccoon eyes (periorbital rash) with complete heart block (P-R dissociation)suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE). Anti-Ro antibodies are used todiagnose neonatal lupus.Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus(NLE):NLE is not an autoimmune condition. It occurs when maternal autoantibodies enter the fetalcirculation (passive transfer). The antibodies responsible for this condition are anti-Roantibody (anti-SSA) and anti-La antibody (anti-SSB).The periorbital rash typically appears within 6 weeks of life and lasts 3-4 months. However, it canbe present at birth. Infants may also have cytopenias and hepatitis, but the most fearedcomplication is congenital heart block. Cardiomyopathy is seen in the most severe cases. Thenoncardiac manifestations of neonatal lupus are usually reversible, whereas congenital heart blockis permanent. Conduction system abnormalities can be detected in utero by fetal echocardiogrambeginning at 16 weeks of gestational age.Fluorinated corticosteroids seem to improve cases of hydrops. Significant conduction systemabnormalities after birth are treated with cardiac pacing and occasionally intravenousimmunoglobulin and steroids, while severe cardiomyopathy may require cardiac transplantation.Transient, noncardiac manifestations are conservatively managed, with topical steroids usedoccasionally to treat the rash.Other options:Anti-Jo antibodies are a type of myositis-specific antibodies. These are not related to neonatallupus.Anti-dsDNA antibodies are specific for SLE (Systemic Lupus erythematosus).Anti-histone antibodies are present in Drug-induced SLE.Note:SS in SSA and SSB stands for Sjögren's syndrome-related. Anti-SSA and anti SSB are antinuclearantibodies and are mainly found in patients with SLE and Sjögren's syndrome.

questions.question: Vikas, a high school student is observed to have an indented 'en coup de sabre' lesion asshown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?708
questions.explanation: En coup de sabre lesion is seen in juvenile localized scleroderma (morphea).715It appears as an indented, vertical, colourless, line of skin on the forehead. The indentation looksas though the person may have been struck (coup) by a sword (sabre). This lesion involves thescalp and/or face and often extend into the central nervous system, resulting in neurologicsequelae such as seizures and headaches.

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture.Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is theprobable diagnosis?

options.B: Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)d) Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)Question 11:Pinky, a small child with Kawasaki disease is admitted to the ward for treatment. Which ofthe following feature would you not expect to see in her?a) Purulent conjunctivitisb) Cervical lymphadenopathy

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario showing swelling of knee joints (arthritis), non-blanching rash in thelower limbs (palpable purpura), along with hematuria and proteinuria (renal involvement) in achild is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).HSP (IgA vasculitis) is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years.It generally follows an upper respiratory tract infection and there is a history of atopy in one-thirdof the cases.The pathology of HSP involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and the deposition of IgA in the affectedblood vessels. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that ofIgA nephropathy.Clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, the hallmark feature of HSP, whichcharacteristically involves the extensor surfaces of arms and legs. Musculoskeletal symptoms suchas arthritis and arthralgia are common. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include abdominal pain,vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Renal involvement may lead to gross or microscopic hematuria,nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. Arapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases. Nephritis usually follows theappearance of the rash.Diagnosis of HSP is primarily based on clinical findings, including the palpable purpura, alongwith the presence of other symptoms. Laboratory tests are not specific to HSP but may shownonspecific markers of inflammation and sometimes elevated levels of IgA. Imaging studies andbiopsies of affected tissues can provide additional diagnostic informationTreatment of HSP is generally supportive, focusing on hydration, pain relief, and nutrition.Corticosteroids may be used in severe cases or for significant gastrointestinal involvement.Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and plasma exchange are occasionally employed for severedisease. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressantslike prednisolone and azathioprine. Complications of HSP can include serious gastrointestinalproblems, kidney disease, and recurrences, but overall, the prognosis for childhood HSP isfavorable. Regular monitoring of blood pressure and urine is recommended to detect and managepotential complications.

questions.question: A worried father brought her 5-year-old son to the pediatrician with a history of fever, rash,irritability, and poor feeding. A few days back, he developed perianal desquamation andnon-purulent conjunctivitis with edema of the hands and feet. He has been up to date withhis immunization. Tongue findings are shown in the image. Which of the following is notlikely to occur in the child?
questions.explanation: The above clinical features are suggestive of Kawasaki disease. Thrombocytosis is a characteristicfinding in Kawasaki disease and commonly occurs in the second week.Important laboratory findings of Kawasaki disease are anemia, elevated ESR, and CRP. Majorcomplications of Kawasaki disease are arteritis and aneurysms of coronary vessels, myocarditis,myocardial infarction, and pericarditis.

questions.question: Nisha presents to the clinic with clinical features suggestive of Kawasaki disease. She wasadmitted to the ward for treatment. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for thisdisease?
questions.explanation: Treatment of choice in Kawaski disease is IV immunoglobulins. IV immunoglobulins along withaspirin have proven beneficial in preventing coronary artery abnormalities.

questions.question: Who amonganeurysms?the following children with Kawasaki's disease is at greatest risk for coronary

options.A: 8 year-old girl with 6 days of high fever and strawberry tongue
options.B: 5-year-old boy with 8 days of fever and CSF pleocytosis
options.C: 2-year-old girl with IVIG treatment at 7th day of fever
options.D: 11-year-old boy with 15 days of fever and low PCV

questions.explanation: An 11-year-old boy with 15 days of fever and low PCV is at the greatest risk for coronaryaneurysms.Risk factors for coronary aneurysms in Kawasaki's disease:•Age younger than 1 year or older than 9 yearsMale sex●•Fever ≥14 days• Hematocrit (PCV) <35 percent••Serum sodium concentration <135 mEq/L• White blood cell count >12,000/mm3• Elevated ESR and CRPAdministration of IVIG during the first 10 days of illness reduces the prevalence of coronaryaneurysms fivefold.
